dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Bitcoin's up almost 50% since its December low of around $10,000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and ethereum's had a pretty wild ride too, up more than half after dropping below a hundred bucks this month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But Goldman Sachs just released this report, uh, they're calling bitcoin the "Myspace of cryptocurrencies."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But Goldman Sachs just released this report, uh, they're calling bitcoin the Myspace of cryptocurrencies.

dialogue_turns.text: Ouch. They really don't see it overtaking ethereum as a store of value, do they?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ouch. They really don't see it overtaking ethereum as a store of value, do they?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Given the importance of real uses in determining the store of value, ether has a high chance of overtaking bitcoin as a dominant store of value, analysts at Goldman Sachs wrote, according to leaked sections of the report shared on Twitter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: No, and they point to ethereum's market cap—$660 billion compared to bitcoin's $250 billion.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now, a leaked report from Wall Street giant Goldman Sachs GS +1.8% has given ethereum, the second-largest cryptocurrency with a market capitalization of around $250 billion compared to bitcoin's $660 billion, a high chance of overtaking bitcoin as a dominant store of valuecalling it the Amazon AMZN -1.4% of information.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is interesting because, like, bitcoin's actually been outperforming ethereum price-wise over the past year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Even with the recent rally, yeah. But Goldman's argument is that ethereum's losing ground in other areas—centralized finance apps, fungible tokens…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even with the recent rally, yeah. But Goldman's argument is that ethereum's losing ground in other areas-centralized finance apps, fungible tokens...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Most decentralized finance (DeFi) applications are being built on the ethereum network, and most non-fungible tokens (NFTs) issued are purchased using ether. The greater number of transactions in ether versus bitcoin reflects this dominance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And a lot of those aren't even being built on ethereum's blockchain anymore, which hurts its use cases.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And a lot of those aren't even being built on ethereum's blockchain anymore, which hurts its use cases.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Most decentralized finance (DeFi) applications are being built on the ethereum network, and most non-fungible tokens (NFTs) issued are purchased using ether.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, you know, bitcoin doesn't support smart contracts, so it kinda limits what you can build on it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, you know, bitcoin doesn't support smart contracts, so it kinda limits what you can build on it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unlike bitcoin, ethereum is not just a value token, meaning it actually fuels all use cases built on top of the ETH blockchain, Kosala Hemachandra, the chief executive of MyEtherWallet, said in emailed comments, pointing to DeFi, NFTs, decentralized applications. How Chinas Digital Currency Could Fracture Global Finance Bitcoin is simply a value token with no clear roadmap.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then there are people saying ethereum's scalability issues and high transaction costs might push its price back down.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then there are people saying ethereum's scalability issues and high transaction costs might push its price back down.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Meanwhile, some think long-awaited upgrades to ethereum, begun at the end of last year and designed to help ethereum scale and reduce its sky-high transaction costs, could help the ether price reach never-before-seen heights.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, one CEO called it just a "value token" that it actually gets in the way of applications built on ETH.

artist_script:
Bitcoin's up almost 50% since its December low of around $10,000.
HostB: Yeah, and ethereum’s had a pretty wild ride too, up more than half after dropping below a hundred bucks this month.
HostA: But Goldman Sachs just released this report, uh, they’re calling bitcoin the "Myspace of cryptocurrencies."
HostB: Ouch. They really don’t see it overtaking ethereum as a store of value, do they?
HostA: No, and they point to ethereum’s market cap—$660 billion compared to bitcoin’s $250 billion.
HostB: Which is interesting because, like, bitcoin’s actually been outperforming ethereum price-wise over the past year.
HostA: Right, bitcoin’s up something like 1,000%? Compared to ethereum’s 300%?
HostB: Even with the recent rally, yeah. But Goldman’s argument is that ethereum’s losing ground in other areas—centralized finance apps, fungible tokens…
HostA: And a lot of those aren’t even being built on ethereum’s blockchain anymore, which hurts its use cases.
HostB: Plus, you know, bitcoin doesn’t support smart contracts, so it kinda limits what you can build on it.
HostA: But then there are people saying ethereum’s scalability issues and high transaction costs might push its price back down.
HostB: Yeah, one CEO called it just a "value token" that it actually gets in the way of applications built on ETH.
HostA: So it’s like… bitcoin has momentum in price, but ethereum might have more utility long-term?
HostB: Seems that way, though Goldman’s pretty skeptical bitcoin can hold onto dominance.
HostA: Either way, both are bouncing back after a rough start to 2021.
HostB: For sure. Wild times in crypto.
